app.title: KID⚡APP
app.subtitle: Family. Tasks. Bitcoin.
app.tagline: Gamified family organization with real Bitcoin rewards

landing.noGuaranteeDesc: There is no guarantee for the value of Bitcoin. Parents should supervise their children accordingly.
landing.familyUseDesc: This app is intended exclusively for private family use and not for commercial purposes.
landing.dataPrivacyDesc: Data is stored securely. No sharing with third parties.
landing.childrenInfoDesc: Kids CANNOT make transactions - you can only RECEIVE Sats. Parents control all Bitcoin payments and wallet management. You don't owe your parents anything!

education.title: Bitcoin Education Center

m1.title: What is Bitcoin?
content: Bitcoin is digital money - like electronic coins
It was invented in 2009 by Satoshi Nakamoto
There are a maximum of 21 million Bitcoin
Bitcoin is decentralized - no bank controls it
Each Bitcoin can be split into 100,000,000 Satoshis
The Bitcoin network is secured by thousands of computers
Transactions are transparent and cannot be reversed
Bitcoin is the first successful digital money

quiz.question: How many Bitcoin exist at maximum?

m2.title: What are Satoshis (Sats)?
content: Satoshis are the smallest unit of Bitcoin
1 Bitcoin = 100,000,000 Satoshis (10^8)
One Satoshi is 0.00000001 Bitcoin
The name honors Satoshi Nakamoto, Bitcoin's creator
Sats are perfect for small everyday transactions
You earn Sats by completing your tasks!
With Sats, you avoid large unwieldy numbers
Sats make Bitcoin practical for kids and small payments

m3.title: How Does Bitcoin Work?
content: Bitcoin works without a middleman or bank
You send Bitcoin directly to other people
The network automatically confirms each transaction
Your address is public, your key is secret
Each transaction is stored in the blockchain
The network checks if you have enough Bitcoin
You don't need permission from anyone to pay
Bitcoin is censorship-resistant - nobody can stop it

quiz.question: Do you need a bank for Bitcoin?

m4.title: Addresses & Wallets
content: A Bitcoin address is your public account number
It looks like: bc1qxy2kgdygjrsqtzq2n0yrf2493p83kkfjhx0wlh
You can give your address to anyone - it's public
A wallet is your digital purse
Your wallet safely stores your private keys
There are different wallet types: Mobile, Desktop, Hardware
Lightning addresses look different than Bitcoin addresses
Your Lightning address is like: spikylip55@walletofsatoshi.com

quiz.question: Can I share my Bitcoin address publicly?

m5.title: Understanding Bitcoin Prices
content: Bitcoin has a market price like stocks
One day Bitcoin costs more, another day less
The price fluctuates because supply & demand changes
There's no central place that controls the price
The price is fair because the market determines it
You can buy Bitcoin at different prices
Each exchange can have different prices
Charts show price development over time

m6.title: Lightning Network Basics
content: Lightning is a network OVER Bitcoin for fast payments
Normal Bitcoin transactions take ~10 minutes
Lightning transactions take seconds!
Lightning channels enable instant payments
Fees are extremely low - often under 1 Sat
You need Lightning for daily payments
It's like the difference between mail and email
Lightning was invented to scale Bitcoin

m7.title: Blockchain Technology
content: A blockchain is a chain of blocks
Each block stores many transactions
Blocks are cryptographically linked together
This makes forgery impossible
The complete Bitcoin ledger is public
Thousands of nodes store the entire blockchain
A new block is added roughly every 10 minutes
The Bitcoin blockchain has run non-stop since 2009

quiz.question: How often does a new block come?

m8.title: Mining Explained
content: Mining is creating new Bitcoin blocks
Miners solve complex math problems
The first miner gets a Bitcoin reward
The network is secured through mining
Mining is hard and uses lots of electricity
The reward is cut in half every 4 years (Halving)
2024: One block gives 3.125 Bitcoin (after halving)
Previously it was 50 Bitcoin per block (2009)

quiz.question: When is the miner reward halved?
How much Bitcoin per block today (2024)?

m9.title: Smart Contracts & DeFi
content: Smart contracts are automatic contracts on blockchain
They execute themselves when conditions are met
DeFi = Decentralized Finance
DeFi apps run on blockchains like Bitcoin/Ethereum
You don't need a bank for DeFi services
DeFi is transparent - everyone can see the code
Risks: Code errors, Scams, Market volatility
DeFi apps are getting more popular

m10.title: Bitcoin vs Gold
content: Bitcoin is often compared to gold
Both are rare: 21 million Bitcoin, limited gold amount
Gold is stored physically, Bitcoin digitally
Bitcoin is faster to send than gold
Gold is older and more well-known than Bitcoin
Bitcoin needs no storage vault
Gold is tangible, Bitcoin is only digital
Both are good stores of value

m11.title: Cryptography in Bitcoin
content: Bitcoin uses cryptography to be secure
Public & private keys are based on math
SHA-256 is Bitcoin's hashing algorithm
ECDSA is used for digital signatures
Your private key generates your public address
This is mathematically easy one direction
But almost impossible to reverse
This makes Bitcoin addresses secure

quiz.question: Can you get the private key from the address?
What are private keys used for?

m12.title: Private & Public Keys
content: Your private key is your password - ABSOLUTELY SECRET!
The private key is a long number: e.g. 48 character hex
Your private key generates your public address
Public addresses are visible to everyone
With your private key you can spend money
Without private key: Nobody can do it for you
If you lose your key: Your money is gone forever
There's no 'password reset' function

quiz.question: Should you share your private key?
What happens if you lose your key?
Can two different private keys exist for one address?

m13.title: Wallet Security
content: Wallets store your private keys
There are different security levels: Hot & Cold Wallets
Hot wallets are online - faster but riskier
Cold wallets are offline - safer but less practical
Hardware wallets are mini-computers for your keys
Multi-Sig wallets need 2 of 3 keys to send money
Backup your seeds/keys in multiple safe places
Use passwords nobody can guess

m14.title: Bitcoin Transactions
content: A Bitcoin transaction has inputs & outputs
Input: Where the Bitcoin money comes from
Output: Where the Bitcoin money goes
You need a private key to sign a transaction
The fee (Fee) is the difference between input & output
Higher fee = faster confirmation
You pay for the blocksize the transaction uses
Every transaction is permanent and irreversible

quiz.question: What is input of a transaction?
Can you reverse a Bitcoin transaction?

m15.title: Proof of Work
content: Proof of Work is Bitcoin's consensus mechanism
Miners must solve a hard math problem
The first one to find the solution gets a reward
The problem gets harder as more miners exist
This makes Bitcoin attacks very expensive
To make a 51% attack you need 51% of compute power
That's nearly impossible and very expensive
Proof of Work protects the blockchain

quiz.question: Does the mining problem get easier or harder?
What does Proof of Work protect?

m16.title: 51% Attack
content: A 51% attack is when someone controls >50% mining power
Then they could change transactions
They could spend Bitcoin twice
That's theoretically possible but practically impossible
It costs billions in hardware & electricity
The Bitcoin community would notice immediately
The attacked chain would fork (split)
Bitcoin is extremely secure because of this

quiz.question: What would the community do in 51% attack?

m17.title: Bitcoin Regulation
content: Different countries regulate Bitcoin differently
Some countries ban Bitcoin, others allow it
El Salvador has Bitcoin as official currency
Countries like Argentina use Bitcoin against inflation
Regulation is important for stability & consumer protection
But too much regulation could weaken Bitcoin
Finding the balance is hard
Regulation changes constantly

quiz.question: Which country has Bitcoin as official currency?

m18.title: Bitcoin Halving
content: Halving is when the miner reward is cut in half
Happens every 4 years or ~210,000 blocks
2024 was the halving to 3.125 BTC
Eventually the reward becomes 0
There are only 64 halvings in Bitcoin history
After the last halving miners earn only through fees
Halving reduces inflation

quiz.question: What's the next reward after halving?

m19.title: Altcoins vs Bitcoin
content: Altcoins are all cryptocurrencies except Bitcoin
There are thousands of altcoins
Some are innovative, some are scams
Bitcoin is the oldest and safest
Bitcoin has the largest network effect
Other coins often have better tech but less security
Diversification is important for beginners
Bitcoin is the safest bet for beginners

m20.title: Future of Bitcoin
content: Bitcoin is becoming more important for the world economy
2024: >50 million people own Bitcoin
Big companies hold Bitcoin as an asset
Countries could use Bitcoin as reserve currency
Lightning makes Bitcoin practical for daily use
You're learning today's technology of the future
Bitcoin could revolutionize finance
The future is exciting for Bitcoin users

quiz.question: How many people own Bitcoin in 2024?
Will Bitcoin be more important in future?
